https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/64744/ : SUCCESS
Are we expecting obmc-console to give a web-socket name for the console?  Why?

Yes, Andrew has same comment. bmcweb uses unix socket id and path (/console0, /console1) for each console. I added websocketid for the path so that bmcweb can simply use it but looks like websocket path is something bmcweb created. I will include you in the discord discussion.
Removed the web-socket path. New interface is added. please take a look.

Can you add more here?
Can you add more of this back ?

          Unix socket identifier for a console. This is used by a process like
          bmcweb to put consoles, most likely host serial consoles, out on
          WebSocket Secure (wss).
Do we then expect bmcweb to then put this out at wss://$bmc/host ? Or since the later patch sets removed the websocket name, where does bmcweb put this out at ?
We still need to put this on /console0 for now. In future bmcweb will replace /console0 with /<leaf> (/host in this case).
This should be fixed - the interface doesn't supply a list, only a single property containing the name of the abstract socket for the object hosting the interface.
Interface name components are always separated by `.` and not `/` (`/` is for object paths).
Please wrap the commit message at 72 columns.
I don't think we need to editorialise here.
That was a comment I received from Gunnar. It is helpful to provide the example.
What does the leading NUL indicate here?  I don't see any obvious reason for it or any documentation.

This is a abstract socket which starts with null character.
Please see the link below for the information.

https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/unix.7.html
       *  abstract: an abstract socket address is distinguished (from a
          pathname socket) by the fact that sun_path[0] is a null byte
          ('\0').  The socket's address in this namespace is given by
          the additional bytes in sun_path that are covered by the
          specified length of the address structure.  (Null bytes in the
          name have no special significance.)  The name has no
          connection with filesystem pathnames.  When the address of an
          abstract socket is returned, the returned addrlen is greater
          than sizeof(sa_family_t) (i.e., greater than 2), and the name
          of the socket is contained in the first (addrlen -
          sizeof(sa_family_t)) bytes of sun_path.

The string type in SDBUS expect a null terminated character stream. This is a abstract socket which starts with null character hence string doesn't work.

I tried the string first and it wasn't working hence moved to byte stream.

Wouldn't it be far more intuitive to have the users insert the NUL?  You're not explicitly trying to make this a path, it appears.  You just called it a "name".

You're already expecting some transformation in bmcweb between internal socket name (`\0bmc-console.host`) and the socket URI, right?

We decided that bmcweb doesn't need to know how it is formed. No we are not doing any transformation in bmcweb we just take the byte stream and connect to it.

Please check bmcweb side change: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62525/8/include/obmc_console.hpp#161
Alright.  Can we get some more documentation here then why this isn't a 'string' or 'path'?  I'd like to not force people to rediscover this conversation in Gerrit when looking at this interface.

Should probably also clarify whether the bytearray includes a null terminator. I think in your current implementation it does not. That's another reason why I agree with Patrick it would be nicer to just publish the string on D-Bus and have consumer code add the null prefix. But I can see the arguments for both approaches.
ok, Added statement related to null termination.
